title: Il disco del giorno: Yellowjackets, "Twentyfive"
text:
[Magazine](/magazine)- Recensioni - 19/09/2024
Il disco del giorno: Yellowjackets, "Twentyfive"
Yellowjackets
"Twentyfive" (Cd +Dvd Heads Up)
Venticinque anni non sono pochi per una formazione musicale, sia pur rimaneggiata nel corso del tempo; gli Yellowjackets sono tra i gruppi di fusion pi√π amati e hanno festeggiato questo anniversario con un ricco pacco dono contenente un Cd registrato dal vivo a Parigi e un Dvd di oltre tre ore e mezza comprendente una recente esibizione in un club di Forl√¨, pi√π numerose altre registrazioni concertistiche, videoclip e interviste con tutti i membri che hanno fatto parte della band in questi anni.
La loro musica si √® sempre mossa con grande abilit√† tra jazz, funk e talvolta pop, rivelando in particolare l‚Äôinfluenza dei Weather Report e Pat Metheny ma trasportando il tutto in una dimensione molto pi√π immediata e fruibile anche dal grande pubblico che di jazz sa poco o nulla; naturalmente la loro abilit√† di strumentisti √® totale, cos√¨ come quella di arrangiatori (il tastierista Russel Ferrante inoltre √® un ottimo compositore), e il risultato finale risulta sempre di un professionismo assoluto e totale gradevolezza, anche se talvolta un po‚Äô easy listening.
"Twentyfive" attinge al meglio della produzione recente con brani di sicuro effetto, dagli echi gospel di "Revelation" al virtuosismo poliritmico di "Free Day", che mette in luce le notevolissime qualit√† del batterista Marcus Baylor, ultimo arrivato nella formazione.
Jimmy Haslip al basso √® sempre impeccabile negli accompagnamenti (ricchi di fantasiose idee ritmiche e linee mai scontate) e negli assoli in cui rende omaggio sia alla cantabilit√† di Jaco Pastorius che al groove instancabile di Stanley Clarke. Bob Mintzer si muove tra sassofoni di vario tipo, clarinetto basso e strumenti elettronici con virtuosismo d‚Äôacciaio e un fraseggio che riporta sempre la palla in ambito jazzistico quando gli altri sembrano volersi avventurare troppo sulla linea del pop. "Geraldine" ha una melodia bellissima e permette a Ferrante di sfoggiare un eccellente assolo di pianoforte, mentre "Jacketown" e "My Old School" si muovono su terreni ritmici ingegnosi accompagnati da armonizzazioni sempre interessanti che tengono presente la lezione di Lyle Mays.
In un ambito come quello fusion, saturo di prodotti tanto mediocri quanto tirati a lucido, gli Yellowjackets rimangono un punto di riferimento per chi cerca musica di qualit√†, forse non rivoluzionaria o troppo originale, ma realizzata con sincerit√†.
Carlo Boccadoro, compositore e direttore d‚Äôorchestra, √® nato a Macerata nel 1963. Vive e lavora a Milano. Collabora con solisti e orchestre in diverse parti del mondo. E‚Äô autore di numerosi libri di argomento musicale.
Questo testo √® tratto da
"Lunario della musica: Un disco per ogni giorno dell'anno" pubblicato da Einaudi, per gentile concessione dell'autore e dell'editore.

author: Erica Martinez
title: The Luxury Loaf Paul Hollywood Calls The 'Rolls Royce' Of Bread
text: The Luxury Loaf Paul Hollywood Calls The 'Rolls Royce' Of Bread Famous baker Paul Hollywood loves bread as much as he [loathes Twinkies](https://www.foodrepublic.com/1458952/dessert-paul-hollywood-hates-twinkies/). Born into a family of bakers, Hollywood has built an empire in the business of baking, most notably penning the best-selling book "100 Great Breads" and hosting baking TV shows in Britain and the United States, including "The Great British Baking Show." Known for his substantial knowledge of bread-making, Hollywood has tasted and sampled wonderful loaves of bread from around the world. The most luxurious bread recipe he's ever sampled, though, is all his own. In 2008, Hollywood created an almond and Roquefort sourdough bread that was sold at London's famed department store, Harrods, for ¬£15 per loaf, or about $19 American dollars in 2024 terms. It was the most expensive bread in Britain at the time, and was made with grade A flour from a specialist miller and Roquefort blue cheese imported from France. Hollywood even referred to it as Rolls Royce of bread, in reference to one of the fanciest cars money can buy. At such a cost, it was certainly not an everyday bread for most people, but a special indulgence. Bake a similar loaf using Paul Hollywood's recipe It is certainly fitting that Paul Hollywood's almond and Roquefort sourdough was sold at Harrods, as the store is famed for selling all things lavish, from designer clothing to costly culinary treats in its very own famed food hall. Enter this culinary emporium and you'll find exotic produce, caviar, luxury chocolates, and of course, freshly-baked bread. While Paul Hollywood's special loaf of bread is no longer sold, and there's no official recipe, the chef does have a recipe for a a Roquefort and walnut loaf, which he suggests serving on a [cheese board](https://www.foodrepublic.com/1407019/must-know-etiquette-rules-cluttered-cheese-boards-charcuterie/) in lieu of crackers. This bread, with the sharp blue cheese and crunchy nuts, would be a sublime treat with a slathering of good butter. You could enjoy a chunk of the bread with a fruit jam like fig, apricot, or cherry. A classic wine choice to accentuate Roquefort's complex flavor is port wine, but a nutty ale, a sharp Riesling, and a smoky Scottish whisky would also be delicious. It may not be the Rolls Royce of bread, but pair it with the right ingredients and it will certainly taste like a million bucks. Other breads with a hefty price tag If shelling out nearly $20 for a loaf of bread seems extreme to you, Paul Hollywood's creation is actually a bargain compared to some other luxury breads around the globe. In 2014, Orchard Pigs bakery in North Wales created a ¬£75 pound loaf that was made with champagne (in place of water) and gold flakes. While in this example, the flakes were dusted on top primarily for decoration purposes, Pan Pina bakery in Algatocin, Spain actually bakes gold and silver right into its luxury sourdough loaves, which sell for an astounding 1,480 per unit, making it the most expensive bread in the world. The ingredients for the bread are kept in a safe, if that tells you anything about its value. Compared to breads such as these ‚Äî which get a little closer to matching the actual price of a Rolls Royce ‚Äì Hollywood's almond and Roquefort sourdough certainly does sound like the more approachable option. It may also sound tastier to those of us who aren't keen on chowing down on silver and gold. We're willing to bet that blue cheese has much more flavor than a flake of precious metal.

author: Thornton Kennedy
title: Barber Shop Has Served as Buckhead‚Äôs Town Hall for 65 Years | News | mdjonline.com
text: Death, taxes and Tommy‚Äôs. These are the three certainties in life. Our existence on this plane is finite. There is a beginning, a middle and an end. There‚Äôs no getting out of it. And even after taking up arms over taxes, we ended up right back where we started, only ostensibly we have some say over where they go. But Tommy‚Äôs? That would be Thomas Barber Shop in the West Paces Ferry Shopping Center. Located at the corner of West Paces Ferry Road and Northside Parkway, it is celebrating 65 years in business. In ever-changing Atlanta, that is an eternity. Tommy‚Äôs is shorthand for the shop started in 1959 by Gilmer ‚ÄúBig Tommy‚Äù Thomas Sr. He and his wife Doris were the backbones of the west Buckhead community through the 1990s, with Thomas giving haircuts and shaves and his wife offering manicures and occasionally homemade biscuits with homemade sausage. There were six chairs, each manned by a barber. On Saturdays, customers filled every seat. A feature obituary in the daily paper called Doris Thomas the yin to her husband‚Äôs yang; he was larger than life, and she was the smiling face greeting patrons. But she held her own with a dry sense of humor. Their son, ‚ÄúLittle Tommy,‚Äù grew up in the West Paces Ferry shop. He did his homework there after school and spent Saturday nights waxing the floors. Today, he is the ‚ÄúTommy‚Äù of Thomas Barber Shop. His father passed away in 1996, and his mother in 2009. There wasn‚Äôt much out that way when Edward Shetzen built the shopping center in 1958. For a point of reference, Lenox Square opened in 1959. Saul Feldman, who owned the iconic deli Snack N‚Äô Shop just up Northside Parkway, told a reporter that before the Department of Transportation completed the expressway in 1957, he could walk the roads in the area and not see a car for hours. According to the article, among the original tenants in Shetzen‚Äôs center were A&P, Wender & Roberts and a Texaco. Tommy‚Äôs followed shortly after and has been a Buckhead mainstay ever since. True to its roots, it is the same as it ever was. Football helmets line a shelf along one wall, and there are enough Coca-Cola bottles, signs and other tchotchkes that it serves as a time capsule of the North Avenue beverage company. There‚Äôs even a Tommy‚Äôs Coke bottle, which the company produced in honor of its 50th anniversary. Longtime Coca-Cola President Robert Woodruff and several of his successors were customers. Like any good old-fashioned barber shop, sports and politics are the constant, as evidenced by the campaign signs in the windows and the window paint a few weekends ago touting the Lovett-Westminster football game. Either Thomas or his dad has given every governor a trim going back six decades, and it‚Äôs a necessary stop on the campaign trail. When Mitt Romney was running for President, he got a haircut at Tommy‚Äôs. I grew up on the other side of Buckhead. The good fellows at the Peachtree Battle Barber Shop cut my hair until I was well out of college. But my wife Lori and I raised our family around the corner from Tommy‚Äôs. Our son loved nothing more than going to get his hair cut, especially on Saturday mornings. The barbers did a nice enough job, and I usually got to catch up with someone I knew. But for Thornton III, there was usually a donut at the end. He would look for the Krispy Kreme box the moment he walked in. I‚Äôd inspect the haircut after and pay, then he would ask me if he could have a donut. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt ask me,‚Äù I‚Äôd say, nodding to Tommy. With that, he developed the soft skill of looking people in the eye, and saying please and thank you to strangers from a very young age. It‚Äôs been a spell since I‚Äôve been in Tommy‚Äôs, but I guarantee it is unchanged.

title: Kaun Banega Crorepati 15: Amitabh Bachchan Shares How Helen Came to India After Escaping the Japanese Invasion During World War 2 | üì∫ LatestLY
text: Megastar Amitabh Bachchan shared an anecdote about the veteran actress Helen, and talked about how she had escaped from the Japanese occupation of Burma in 1943, during the World War 2, and came to India. Helen is a well known dancer and is known for her character roles. Born in Rangoon, Burma (now known as Myanmar), Helen‚Äôs family trekked to Dibrugarh, Assam in 1943 in order to escape from the Japanese occupation of Burma. Later on, Helen got her major break at the age of 19 in 1958, when she performed on the song "Mera Naam Chin Chin Chu" in the movie Howrah Bridge. Kaun Banega Crorepati 15: Amitabh Bachchan Opens Up About Father‚Äôs Income and His Early Life Struggles. With legendary actor Shammi Kapoor, she did many hit dance numbers like "Suku Suku" in Junglee, "Yamma Yamma" in China Town, and "O Haseena Zulfonwali" in Teesri Manzil. Amitabh, who is currently hosting the quiz based reality show Kaun Banega Crorepati 15 welcomed the roll over contestant Lalit Kumar to the hot seat. For Rs 25 lakh, he was asked: ‚ÄúWhich of these actresses was born in Myanmar and later escaped with her family to India during the Second World War?‚Äù The options given were -- Sulochana, Suraiya, Nadira, and Helen. The correct answer was Helen. Amitabh then went on to say, ‚ÄúHelen and her family escaped Myanmar...called Burma back then. In order to escape and come to India, they had to trek alternately through miles of wilderness passing through rivers, mountains and forests. In order to escape from the Japanese occupation of Burma, she had to do this in 1943.‚Äù ‚ÄúShe became a popular actress in our film industry. Watching her dance would leave one enthralled,‚Äù shared the Brahmastra actor. Kaun Banega Crorepati 15: Amitabh Bachchan Expresses Admiration for His ‚ÄòFavourite‚Äô Waheeda Rehman, Calls Her ‚ÄòExemplary Artiste‚Äô. Helen has shared screen with Big B in the movies like Mohabbatein, Don, Sholay, Amar Akbar Anthony, The Great Gambler and Ram Balram. In the movie Sholay, she had a special appearance in the track "Mehbooba Mehbooba". Talking about the same, Amitabh added: ‚ÄúI had the good fortune of working with her in a few films. She's a kind and compassionate woman. She used to look after everyone. We pray she stays in good health. She's old now.‚Äù
